div.p:
Hic quaeri solet Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 1 [n.1], (I, 91, ll. 15-16). . This is distinction 7 of the first book which continues with respect to the preceding because after the Master determined about divine generation with respect to mode and form, he begins here to determine about those thing that have to do with the power of acting. And he divides this into two because in the first place he inquires whether the power of generating belongs to Father eternally, secondly whether this power is found in the Son. The second begins at
item quaeritur a quibusdam Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 2 [n.1], (I, 93, ll. 20). .

The first in three parts because he first moves the question, second he introduces his determination about it, in the third place from the words of Augustine he offer an explanation of some objection. The second begins at
cui versutiae Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 1 [n.1/3], (I, 91, ll. 19). . The third begins at
sed vehementer Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 1 [n.2/5], (I, 92, ll. 6-7). .

The second principal part is divided
in three. The first moves the question and puts its response, secondly he shows the explanation of his response. The second begins at Secunda ibi,
ita etiam, cum dicitur Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 2 [n.4/7], (I, 94, ll. 17). . And this is the opinion and division in general of the present distinction.
Whether active generation in the Father is of immense perfection absoltely.

That not, no suppositable ratio speaks a perfection, therefore there is not an active generation. The consequence holds because active generatio is a suppositable ratio of the Father. The antecedent is clear because then in the divine there would be another goodness besides the essential goodness. Likewise because to not produce, would be to argue an imperfection, and thus neither the divine essence nor the Holy Spirit would be essentially perfect.

In the second place, it would follows that every divine person would not be as perfect as the essence. The consequence is clear because any person lacks some supposibile ratio becase the Father does not have the suppositable ratio of the Son, nor of the Holy Spirit, nor of the converse.

In the third place, it would follow that the theologian evidently would be able to prove that there is generation in the divine. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because it is evidently able to be deduced that whatever God is, he is everything that it is better to be than not to be absolutely, since he
that which nothing greater is able to be thought Anselmus, Prosologion, 3, (I, 103, ll. 1-2) , as says
Anselm in Prosologion .
In opposition, the generation in the divine is the Father, but the Father is of immense perfection or is immense perfection, therefore.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
First conclusion: though from the Son and the Holy Spirit no divine word is able to be generated, nevertheless something is producible through the speaking of the Son or the Holy Spirit. The first is clear because otherwise there would be many possible words in the divine, indeed de facto this should be put against faith. The second part is proved because through the speaking of the whole Trinity all created things are produced and producibile things are able to be produced. This is clear through that Psalm
he spoke and things were made Psalmus 32:9 et Psalmus 148:5 . Again John 1
through him all things were made Ioannes 1:3 .

First corollary: that not every speaking with the word speaks the word, though perhaps the converse is true. This is clear because speaking the divine word is precisely and properly to the Father, but speaking with the word suits three, as is clear through the conclusion. From which it seems to follow that, though every internal speaking is understanding, nevertheless not every understanding is speaking.

The second corollary: the eternal productive power of the Word is not a pure relation or merely something related. This is clear because a relation is not a ratio of the Father's being absolutely, therefore it is not a ratio of acting. From which it seems to follow that just as the essence is the ratio of the Father's being, so also it seems to be the ratio of producing the Word. From which it follows further that power of generating the divine word speaks something absolute with respespec to what is principally signified, though he knows with respect to what is begotten.

The third corollary: though the word has being and act from the Father, nevertheless the Father and Son produce equally freely. This is clear because the Son is not determined by the Father with some natural necessity, therefore they produce the Holy Spirit equally freely, just as the Father himself generates the word. The antecedent is clear from what has been said above. Further it follows that it is as repugnant to the Word to intrinsecally depend as it is necessarily repugnant to it that the Father demanded or needed.
This is clear because all things convey an imperfection. This corollary is against
Scotus, in book one, distinction 6 Scotus, I, d. 6, xxx .

Third conclusion: that though it is not a kind of perfection in generation that something is produced through it from non being to being, nevertheless that something is able to generate, because that being is not evidently probable, is absolutely a kind of immense perfection. The first part is clear because, if this were so, it would follow that divine generation would lack some perfection absolutely. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because the Son neither through generation nor through some other is produced from non being to being. The second part is proved because, if this were so, it would follow that the that God is three would be efficaciously demonstrable and would be evidently proved. The consequent was disproved earlier. The consequence is clear because the duality of the persons and the trinity of them would be proved in the same way. The third part is proved because it would be able to produce a finite word and would be a perfection of a created memory. Therefore the power to produce the uncreated will be an immense perfection of uncreated memory. This is confirmed because the understanding
of the father is an immense perfection, therefore. The consequence is clear because to speak of the Father is to speak formally his understanding, and consequently it is a vital act and a kind of immense perfection.

First corollary: it is not of lesser perfection to speak the notional aspect of the Father as it is to understand his intrinsic and essential aspect. This is proved because each is of immense perfection, as is clear through the conclusion.

The second corollary: as he is able formally to be blessed in his notional utterance so he is able to be beatified in his essential understanding. This is clear because the Father is beatified formally in his every immense perfection. And these are two corollaries against the position of
Scotus, in distinction 6 of the first book .

Third corollary: no reason separated from faith and clear vision certifies why the Father in the divine does not produce or generate many words or many sons. I mean this according to the common law. This is clear because it is believed by faith alone that only one person in the divine is able to be generated. This is confirmed because every potency and perfect which the Father has, the Son and Holy Spirit have, there by this reason it is not able to be convincingly concluded that he would not be able to produce many sons. This is clear from what has been said. From this the responsive corollary is clear that, though the generation of the eternal word is absolutely immense perfection, nevertheless the negation of it not in one either is the privation of perfection or not, nevertheless the negation of it in one is the privation of perfection. This is clear through Lord Giles, in distinction four of book 1, part 1, question 2, in the solution of the first principal argument where he says
something is a kind of perfection in one supposite that is not a perfection in the other, therefore, though is a kind of perfection in the Son that it is generated, nevertheless it is not necessary that is a kind of perfection in the Father and Holy Spirit Aegidius Romanus, I, d. 4, p. 1, q. 2 . This corollary is also apparent through what has been said.

Against the first part of the first conclusion: what the principle of generation is suitable to in the divine, to the same thing is it suitable to generate the divine world. But the principle of generation suits the Son and the Holy Spirit, therefore. The major is clear because for as much as habit or latitude is proper to the act of generation, it is required to the same degree for the productive principle of the word. The minor is clear because the essence seems to be the principle of generation.

In the second place, the Son and the Holy Spirit have the perfection absolutley which the Father has, therefore from the Son and the Holy Spirit the divine word is able to be generated. The consequence holds because through what has been said to be able to generate is absolutely an immense perfection. The antecedent is a catholic truth.

Against the second and third corollary: if they were true, it would follow that God would act externally merely naturally and necessarily. The consequent is false because he acts merely freely and contingently. The consequence is clear because in the same mode and by the same action God produces his word and his creatures as is clear through the corollaries.

Against the second conclusion: in every producing thing it is required that it has the nature of a produced terminus or of a producing terminus, there the Father in some mode precedes the Son. The consequence holds and the antecedent known because the opposite seems against nature and reason.

In the second place, the Son is not able to make anything except that which he sees the Father doing, therefore the Son depends on the Father in his own acts. The antecedent is clear because in the Gospel of John. And the consequence seems known because, if Socrates is not able to act unless he first sees another acting, then it seems that in this acting depends on the other.

In the third place, every thing begun presupposes its own beginning, therefor the Father precedes the Son. The consequence holds because the Father is the beginning of the Son. The antecedent is proved because that the cause exists is prior to its being a cause because it follows, a is a cause, therefore it is, but the converse is not true. But the beginning is not only presupposed by what was begun for the being of its cause or its beginning, but also in its absolute being, therefore.

Against the third corollary: The Father is free from himself and the Son is not but from the Father, therefore the Son is less free than the Father. Consequence is valid and the antecedent is clear because whatever the Son is and has, he has from the Father.

In the second place, from words of Christ in Luke 2
it is necessary for me to be about the things of my Father Lucas 2:49 , therefore he acts necessarily and not freely. The consequence is clear because through the word being it seems that something is conveyed in necessary terms.

Against the last corollary: the Son proceeds both perfectly from the Father in the distinct person and perfectly if it were to proceed
distinct, personally, and essentially, but the Son would depend on the Father and would presuppose him, therefore also now.

Against the second part of the third conclusion: everything that is more communicable the more perfect it is, but therefore God is able to communicate himself by producing. This is probable because most perfect thing is the most communicable thing. This mode is probable because God is the most perfect being.

In the second place, it is repugnant that the intellectual nature is independent that it does not produce some word expressive of it. But the divine essence is of this type, therefore. The minor is known and the major is proved because it is not repugnant to the finite memory to speak itself through a comprehensive word expressive of itself, therefore it is not repugnant to an immense and infinite memory, therefore. The consequence because God is comprehensive of himself through his understanding and a consequence is productive and formative of an immense word and not through creation, therefore through generation, and the intent is reached. The argument is founded on what is said by Augustine, in the book on the cognition of the blessed life, where he says
since the mind knows itself as if it generates a mind similar to itself Augustinus, De cognitione verae vitae, XI . This is the foundation and means of Hugolinus.

In the third place, whatever is the productive principle from a formal ratio of something according to its own formal ratio in whatever it is will be the productive principle of something from itself. But the intellect having an object present to itself is from the formal ratio the principle of the begotten knowledge, therefore when such a thing is in God, it follows that there is a begotten knowledge there. This is the argument of
Scotus, in distinction 2 of the first book Scotus, I, d. 2 .

Against the second corollary: if it were true, it would follow that the suppositable ratio would be equally the beatificative ratio of the created intellect just as the divine essence. The consequent is false, therefore.
Iohannes de Marchia Ioannes de Marchia, XXX ,

Against the third corollary: relations of the same species are not able to be multiplied unless according to a natural distinction. But such a distinction should not be put in the divine essence, therefore there are many filiations, and as a consequence there are not able to be many sons.
Saint Thomas, in the first part, question 41, article 6 Aquinas, Summa Theologiae I, q. 41, a. 6, resp. (4, 432).

In the second place, precise reason why the Father is not able to generate another Son is because filiation of this type is the total subsisting quantity, hence it is not able to be multiplied.
Aureoli, book 1, distinction 7, question 2, article 3 Aureolus, I, d. 7, q. 2, a. 3 (xxx) .

In the third place, because it is repugnant that there are many relations of the same ratio in the same foundation except on account a diversity of absolutes. But in God there are not able to be many absolute relations, therefore there are not many such relations, and as a consequence there are not many sons.
Ockam, distinction 7 of book 1, question 3, article 2 Ockham, Ordinatio I, d. 7, q. 3 (3, 153, l. 24 - 154, l. 4). .

In the fourth place, the adequate act to a productive principle which is always standing is not compatible with another act of the same ratio from the same principle. But so it is about the act of paternal generation in the divine, therefore there are not able to be many sons.
Henry, quolibet 6, quaestione prima Henricus, Quodlibet VI, q. 1 .

In the fifth place, if there are able to be many productions in the divine of the same reason, then there would be infinite amount. But whatever is able to be in God is there de facto, therefore he would form there infinite generations.
Scotus, in his Quolibet, question 2 Scotus, Quodlibet, q. 2 .

In the sixth place, to produce many knowledges in the divine is absolutely impossible from the fact that this knowledge would not be in the divine nature unless it were God unless absolutely the whole infinite latitude of possible knowledge produced through the mode of knowledge or of the word were the production, therefore. This argument explains why many sons are not generated, and as a consequence is held not only by faith.
Hugolinus, distinction 7 of book 1, question 2, conclusion 2 Hugolinus, I, d. 7, q. 2 , see there.

In the seventh place, the Father is not able to know himself by a knowledge other than in the mode that he knows himself, therefore he is not able to produce another world. The consequence is known because every word is knowledge. The antecedent is clear because the Father now knows himself infinitely in as much as he is wisdom, in as much as he is his essence as is clear through
Augustine, De Trinitate, in book XV, chapter 14 Augustinus, De Trinitate, XV, c. 14 . The antecedent is confirmed because either this word would be
more perfect or less or equally perfect. None of these things should be said, therefore.

Octavo, si aliud verbum producere posset non perfecte Pater se dixisset. Consequens est falsum. Istae tres rationes sunt
Bonsemblantes quas ponit in suo primo quaestione, Bonsemblantes, XXX
qua quaerit utrum potentia generandi sit in Filio.

Nono, contra illud corollarium videtur esse processus
Domini Aegidi distinctione 7 primi, quaestione ultima
Aegidius Romanos
ubi dat differentiam inter verbum nostrum et divinum. Prima quia verbum divinum semper de scientia nascitur nostrum vero verbum quandoque de ignorantia. Secunda quia scientia Dei est immutabiliter stabilis nostra vero armissibilis[?]. Tertia quia verbum divinum est informae semper autem nostrum non est formatum. Quarta quia divinum nascitur de tota scientia Patris, non autem nostrum potest formari de omnibus speciebus in memoria contentis ex quibus videtur concludi unitas omini verbi et pluralitas nostri.

Ad primum, dicitur quod essentia esse principium generationis divini verbi potest sumi dupliciter. Primo modo ut ipsa essentia in se absolute considerata et sic non est principium nec generat nec generatur. Alio modo capitur ut subsistit paternitati vel ut est in supposito paterno, et sic potest dici principium generationis, et tunc minor est falsa.
Ad secundum, negatur consequentia quia, licet illud posset sit perfectionis in Patre, non tamen in Filio autem Spiritu Sancto.

Secundo, potest dici quod, licet Filius habeat omnem perfectionem et potentiam, non tamen potest exire in actum generationis quia non habet proprietatem generationi congruentem, scilicet paternitatem, sed oppositam, scilicet filiationem.
Tertio, posset dici quod eadem perfectio et eadem potentia est qua Pater generat et Filius gignitur quia in nulla re absoluta differentialis.

Quarto, cum dicitur quod Filius non habet potentiam generandi quam habet pater potest dupliciter intelligi. Uno modo filius non habet potentiam generandi, id est quam possit generare et sic conceditur. Alio modo non habet potentiam quam possit gigni seu generari vel genitus esse qua potentia pater est potens, ut generet et sic negatur.

Ad secundum, negatur consequentia, et ad probationem dicitur quod, si modus et actio sumantur nominaliter et realiter, tunc conceditur antecedens et negatur consequentia quia unicus est modus quo producit Deus. Si vero sumatur modaliter et adverbialiter, tunc antecedens negatur.

Ad primum contra secundam conclusionem, negatur antecedens universaliter et, licet increatis veritatem[?] habeat, non tamen in divinis quia mensura divinae productionis ad intra est aeternitas. Ideo non est ibi praeexigentia nec praecessio tam ratione identitatis essentiae quam illationis corollative.
Ad secundum, negatur consequentia ratione identitatis naturae.
Ad tertium, loquendo conformiter ad praedictam posset dici quod in divinis proprie nihil est principatum quia hoc importat imperfectionem.
Secundo posset negari antecedens loquendo de suppositione vel praeexigentia, sicut debet intelligi conclusio et suum corollarium.

Ad quartum, negatur consequentia ratio identitatis naturae ad illud luce dicitur quod li oportet non denotat oportunitatem necessitatis sed potius congruitatis. Secundo dicitur quod si notet necessitatem, non tamen consequentis sed consequentiae[?] et talis non repugnat libertati, sed simul stant. Tertio posset dici quod ibi loquitur secundum humanitatem hic autem loquor de sola trinitate ideo non sequitur.
Ad aliud negatur consequentia simpliciter.

Ad primum contra tertiam conclusionem, dicitur quod non sequitur evidenter Deus est infinita bonitas et libertas, ergo communicat se producendo Filium sibi aequalem quia antecedens
est concedendum de essentia divina et Spiritu Sancto, et tamen non communicant se illo modo.

Ad secundum, diceret Philosophus vel fidei adversarius quod, licet memoria increata intelligeret se, non tamen per verbum distinctum ab ea realiter vel personaliter, et diceret ultra quod melius et perfectius esset quod memoria creata esset met sua intellectio seu notitia quam quod intelligat per verbum vel notitiam ab ea distinctis.
Item per idem posset concludi quod essentia divina generaret verbum quod est falsum.

Ad auctoritatem Augustini dicitur quod solum loquitur de mente creata quod patet per hoc quod dicit generat quasi sibi similem quia constat quod verbum divinum simpliciter est non quasi aequale et simile Patri et per hoc voluit nos Augustinus manuducere ad sic esset in mente increata, sed per hoc non convincit evidenter.
Ad aliud Philosophus et adversarius negarent maiorem. Ad aliud sequitur quod ratio suppositibilis, etc. Conceditur consequens.

Ad primum contra tertium corollarium, dicitur quod ratio fundatur super falso. Primo quod Deus non possit multiplicare individua sub una specie, error. Item quod formae non recipiunt divisionem sine materia, error. Isti sunt duo articuli condemnati super quibus ratio videtur fundari.

Ad secundum, negatur antecedens quia si ratio valeret posset concludi quod ibi non essent tres personae quia quaelibet divina persona quantitatem divinam subsistentem includit naturaliter et essentialiter ut tenet fideles, ergo eodem modo sequitur quod non sit nisi una persona ratio. Patet a simili.

Ad tertium, primo posset negari maior per adversarium quia
secundum Alphonsum Alphonsus Vargas, XXX
non plus repugnat esse pluries in eodem fundamento relationes quam plura activa eiusdem rationis sed secundum concedit ipse met
Ockham ibidem, Ockham, Ordinatio I, d. 7, q. 3 (3, 153, l. 24 - 154, l. 4)
ergo.
Ad quartum, dicitur quod si ratio concluderet per simile probaretur quod Pater solus esset in divinis quod est falsum, ideo fidei adversarius illam negaret maiorem.

Ad quintum, negatur consequentia de forma quia nec sequitur in creaturis iste potest generare duos filios, ergo infinitos quia si ratio valeret etiam posset inferri duae personae sunt productae ergo infinitae quod est haereticum.

Ad sextum, negatur antecedens ad probationem dicitur quod non valet quia latitudo tota perfectionis quae est in omnibus tribus perfectionis est in solo Patre et notitia tota possibilis et totus amor et tota perfectio, ex quo posset inferri quod non sunt plura sumpta, sed solum Patris. Patet ergo quod non sequitur Filius est tota latitudo perfectionis, etc. Ergo patet sic arguendo Pater est tota perfectio deitatis, ergo nullus alius ab eo est immensa perfectio deitatis.

Ad septimum, negatur consequentia ad probationem dicitur quod non ostendit evidenter quia, licet omnem verbum sit notitia, tamen posset dici quod ab eodem verbo notitia qui est Pater posset esse aliud verbum. Secundo, posset dici quod dato quod ratio probaret quod Pater non posset aliud verbum gignere, non tamen ostendit quod Filius non possit generare. Tertio, dicitur quod si sumitur antecedens pro notitia in qua tunc supponit quod deberet probare quia secundum Augustinum
Pater omnia novit in se et omnia novit in verbo. Augustinus, XXX
Ex quo patet quod verbum est notitia in qua Pater novit dicere, ergo Pater non potest alia notitia nosce se sumendo sic notitiam. Patet quod petit principium quia supponit quod est probandum. Si vero sumatur notitia qua pater noscit, tunc adversarius negaret consequentiam primam.
Per hoc patet ad 8m quod non sequitur Pater perfecte se dicit, ergo non potest aliud verbum dicere, et respondeo semper sicut diceret infidelis vel fidei adversarius.

Ad processum Domini Aegidii dicitur quod solum intendit differentia probare inter verbi dei et nostri, tamen per hoc non probat evidenter quin Pater posset alium Filium generare et alium Spiritum Sanctum spirare.

Ad primum in oppositum, negatur antecedens. Secundo modo posset dici quod sicut hanc esse personam non dicit perfectionem simpliciter, tamen esse personam dicit perfectionem simpliciter sic esse suppositum dicit perfectionem simpliciter, licet hoc suppositum esse non dicit.
Ad secundum, patet per idem quod, licet Patris suppositum non sit suppositum Filii nec econverso quia tamen uterque est suppositum nihil deficit eis perfectionis.

Hic quaeri solet. Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 7, c. 1 [n.1], (I, 91, ll. 15-16).
Haec distinctio continet quattuor conclusiones.

Prima: quod Patrem generare Filium non est aliquid subiectum potentiae divinae autem vocati est, tamen aliqua potentia vel voluntas, nec tamen sequitur personam quae hoc potest vel vult potentiorem esse persona quae hoc non potest vel vult

Secunda conclusio: quod, licet Filius non possit generare, hoc tamen non est ex impotentia sed ex proprietate quia non oportet eum generare aliter qua ratione Filius generasset nepotem ferri nepos generasset pro nepotem, et sic sine statu. Filius ergo non potest esse Pater nec sui nec alterius nec hoc provenit ex impotentia, sed ex proprietate generationis qua sic est Filius quod non potest esse Pater.
Tertia conclusio: quod Pater est potens natura sine essentia Filium gignere et eadem potentia est in Filio qua potuit gigni et in Patre qua potuit generare.

Quarta conclusio: licet sit eadem potentia qua Pater potest gignere et Filius gigni, tamen est alia proprietas seu notio qua Pater est genitor et alia qua Filius est genitus ita quod referendo posse generare et posse generari ad proprietatem, tunc Pater habet aliquod posset quod non habet Filius et econverso. Et illud posse est notionale et relativi quia non dicit quid sed ad
ad
bene non sequitur Pater habet potentiam generandi et Filius non ergo aliquam potentiam vel aliquod posset habet Pater quod non habet Filius sed eadem potentia Pater generat qua Filius generatur quia Pater potest generare et Filius generari sicut etiam non sequitur Pater habet potentiam quod sit Pater et hanc non habet Filius, ergo aliquam potentiam habet Pater quam non habet Filius.
